Does Art really hate Religion?

Stefan Kielbasiewicz questions whether the art world really has walked away from its spiritual past

Editors' Picks: The International Shakespeare Festival

With the International Shakespeare Festival opening this week, the Arts Editors take a look at what's in store and pick their favourites from the line-up

Mind Over Matter

Art photographer Roger Ballen talks to Joel Down about his acclaimed Outland series and the process of creating rather than capturing images

Once Bitten, Twice Shia

Tess Pullen considers our different reactions to male and female performance artists

No Holds Bard

Daniel Bowen gives us a preview of the diverse line up as The International Shakespeare festival comes to York

Warning: Contains Real Women

After the controversial removal of Rupi Kaur's Instagram post, Lara Shannon asks why real women are so unacceptable within social media

The Fine Art of Farce

By James Bithell

Renowned journalist, playwright and novelist Michael Frayn is one of York's recent honorary degree recipients. Chris Owen chats to the man of many talents about student life, Sylvia Plath and the fine art of farce.

Classics are the New Black

Penguin have recently released a new set of affordable and accessible classics - The Little Black Classics range. But do such iconic texts need to be made more accessible? Can these 'new' texts still be considered classics? Zoe Thomson considers the impact of Penguin's new endeavour.

So Long, Page 3

Fringe success Josie Long chats to Grace Marsh about Edinburgh's infamous comedy festival, Twitter and Page 3

The Shock Market

Joel Down considers whether pieces of art still have the capacity to shock their audience.

Ask the Editors: Marcus Lyon's 'mankind on the move'

Photographer Marcus Lyon presents his vision of a claustropobic future. Jaz Hayward and Lara Swan discuss 'Exodus: migrations, megacities and mankind on the move'

Sugar, Spice and Not Everything's Nice

19 year-old photography student, Hannah Altman, releases a photographic series criticising the unrealistic portrayals of women in the media. Lara Shannon considers the significance of Altman's work and its instant popularity online.

York: a UNESCO City of Media Arts

As York wins the accolade of a UNESCO City of Media Arts, Angelica Curzi considers what the title really means and what's in store for the city over the coming year.

Storytelling at Say Owt Slam

At York's second Say Owt Slam, Sophia Walker, BBC Scottish National Slam Champion, talks to Tess Pullen about her journey into spoken word poetry and her success.

Nevermind Nostalgia

Nick Gentry talks to Lily Papworth about floppy disks, film reels and the significance of yesterday's technology.

#standwithpriya

Nazli Pulatmen looks at the impact of the comic, Priya's Shakti, and its representation of rape victims.

Vagina of the Valley

Lara Swan explores censorship after the arrest of artist Megumi Igarashi for 3D printing her vagina to turn it into a kayak.

Not Quite Selfie School

Stefan Kielbasiewicz defends London City Lit's infamous "selfie" course as self-portraiture

The Art of Being Selfish

Deborah Lam examines the centralisation of art in London.

Congratulations - you've been Nobilified

With selfies taking the world by storm, Nobilified embraces the planet's favourite obsession and takes it to a whole new level.

Trash Talk

Joel Down talks to artist Francisco de Pajaro about glorifying rubbish instead of throwing it away

Berlin's Cultural Uprising

Lily Papworth considers the significance of the Berlin Wall in the city's cultural journey over the past 25 years

Is It Art?: Photojournalism v Privacy

Paolo Patruno captures intimate moments of motherhood in Africa, through his photgraphy project, 'Birth is a Dream'

Belinda Love Lee's Guide to all things Freelance

Belinda Love Lee talks to Lily Papworth about her Freelance illustration business and her journey to success

From London Tower the Poppies flow

By James Bithell

Emma Allden reflects upon London's commemorative art installation at the Tower of London - the Poppies.

"Rage, Rage against the dying of the light"

Ada Cheong looks back on the life of the man who "did not go gentle into that good night"

Vandalise this space

Declan Dillane ponders the evolution of graffiti - from vandalism to institutionalised art

The art of the illusionist

Britain's Got Talent llusionist James More chats to Jasmin Hayward about playing with fire

Too hard to keep

By James Bithell

Deborah Lam evaluates photos that were never intended as art

"We're going for 'immersive'"

By James Bithell

Lily Papworth interviews student director Anna Marshall on the challenges of The Threepenny Opera
